message_1: A sample of Iodine-131 decays with a half-life of 8.02 days. If the initial activity of the sample was 120 μCi, what is the activity of the sample after 24.06 days?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the radioactive decay formula:

A(t) = A₀ * (1/2)^(t / T)

Where:
A(t) is the activity of the sample at time t,
A₀ is the initial activity of the sample,
t is the time that has passed (in days),
T is the half-life of the substance (in days).

Given:
A₀ = 120 μCi
T = 8.02 days
t = 24.06 days

We can now plug these values into the formula:

A(24.06) = 120 * (1/2)^(24.06 / 8.02)

A(24.06) = 120 * (1/2)^(3)

A(24.06) = 120 * (1/8)

A(24.06) = 15 μCi

So, the activity of the Iodine-131 sample after 24.06 days is 15 μCi.
